db:abstract.db:para: The QMap::const_iterator class provides an STL-style const iterator for QMap.

db:section.db:title: Detailed Description
db:section.db:para: QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator allows you to iterate over a QMap. If you want to modify the QMap as you iterate over it, you must use QMap::iterator instead. It is generally good practice to use QMap::const_iterator on a non-const QMap as well, unless you need to change the QMap through the iterator. Const iterators are slightly faster, and can improve code readability.

The default QMap::const_iterator constructor creates an uninitialized iterator. You must initialize it using a QMap function like QMap::cbegin(), QMap::cend(), or QMap::constFind() before you can start iterating. Here's a typical loop that prints all the (key, value) pairs stored in a map:
Here's an example that removes all the items whose value is greater than 10:
And here the same behavior with erase_if()
db:section.db:programlisting: erase_if(map, [](const QMap<QString, int>::iterator it) { return it.value() > 10; });
db:section.db:para: Unlike QHash, which stores its items in an arbitrary order, QMap stores its items ordered by key.

Multiple iterators can be used on the same map. If you add items to the map, existing iterators will remain valid. If you remove items from the map, iterators that point to the removed items will become dangling iterators.

db:warning.db:para: Iterators on implicitly shared containers do not work exactly like STL-iterators. You should avoid copying a container while iterators are active on that container. For more information, read Implicit sharing iterator problem.

db:section.db:title: [alias] const_iterator::iterator_category
db:section.db:para: A synonym for std::bidirectional_iterator_tag indicating this iterator is a bidirectional iterator.

db:section.db:title: const_iterator::const_iterator()
db:section.db:para: Constructs an uninitialized iterator.
Functions like key(), value(), and operator++() must not be called on an uninitialized iterator. Use operator=() to assign a value to it before using it.

db:section.db:title: const_iterator::const_iterator(const QMap<Key, T>::iterator &other)
db:section.db:para: Constructs a copy of other.

db:section.db:title: const Key &const_iterator::key() const
db:section.db:para: Returns the current item's key.

db:section.db:title: const T &const_iterator::value() const
db:section.db:para: Returns the current item's value.

db:section.db:title: const T &const_iterator::operator*() const
db:section.db:para: Returns the current item's value.
Same as value().

db:section.db:title: QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator &const_iterator::operator++()
db:section.db:para: The prefix ++ operator (++i) advances the iterator to the next item in the map and returns an iterator to the new current item.
Calling this function on QMap::end() leads to undefined results.

db:section.db:title: QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator const_iterator::operator++(int)
db:section.db:para: This is an overloaded function.
The postfix ++ operator (i++) advances the iterator to the next item in the map and returns an iterator to the previously current item.

db:section.db:title: QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator &const_iterator::operator--()
db:section.db:para: The prefix -- operator (--i) makes the preceding item current and returns an iterator pointing to the new current item.
Calling this function on QMap::begin() leads to undefined results.

db:section.db:title: QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator const_iterator::operator--(int)
db:section.db:para: This is an overloaded function.
The postfix -- operator (i--) makes the preceding item current and returns an iterator pointing to the previously current item.

db:section.db:title: const T *const_iterator::operator->() const
db:section.db:para: Returns a pointer to the current item's value.

db:section.db:title: bool operator==(const QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator &lhs, const QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator &rhs)
db:section.db:para: Returns true if lhs points to the same item as the rhs iterator; otherwise returns false.

db:section.db:title: bool operator!=(const QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator &lhs, const QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator &rhs)
db:section.db:para: Returns true if lhs points to a different item than the rhs iterator; otherwise returns false.

db:section.db:title: Obsolete Members for const_iterator
db:section.db:para: The following members of class const_iterator are deprecated. We strongly advise against using them in new code.

db:section.db:title: [deprecated in 6.2] QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator &const_iterator::operator+=(QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator::difference_type n)
db:section.db:bridgehead: [deprecated in 6.2] QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator operator+(QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator it, QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator::difference_type j)
[deprecated in 6.2] QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator operator+(QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator::difference_type j, QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator it)
[deprecated in 6.2] QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator operator-(QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator it, QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator::difference_type j)
[deprecated in 6.2] QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator operator-(QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator::difference_type j, QMap<Key, T>::const_iterator it)
db:section.db:para: This function is deprecated since 6.2. We strongly advise against using it in new code.
Use std::next, std::prev or std::advance instead.
Moves an iterator by n positions. These operations can be expensive for large values of n. QMap iterators are not random access.
